The preparation of Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) by electrochemical two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e- ORR) and water oxidation reaction (2e- WOR) is a highly desirable method that can be green, clean and safe. However, the sluggish reaction kinetics and poor 2e- ORR and WOR selectivity severely limits scale-up applications. To resolve these challenges, research on cost-effective catalysts have been intensively explored, which have made great progress. Herein, we first introduced the fundamental chemistry and catalytic mechanism of ORR and WOR, including the possible reaction pathways, the binding modes of oxygen and water on the catalytic sites, and the energy-barrier diagrams of each stage of the reaction obtained by theoretical calculations. Then, the current progress of catalyst research for electrocatalytic synthesis of H2O2 is discussed. Among them, single-atom catalysts as well as molecular catalysts are the hot spots of current research. Single-atom catalysts can reduce the amount of precious or non-precious metals used, and maintain catalytic activity while reducing costs; meanwhile, molecular catalysts have the advantages of single reaction performance, high selectivity, and clear mechanism, which are easy to design and grasp. Finally, on the basis of previous studies, the remaining challenges and development prospects of the current research on electrocatalytic production of H2O2 are discussed, and suggestions are provided for the development of this field in the future. Graphical Abstract In this review, we first introduced the fundamental mechanism and testing equipment of 2e- ORR and WOR. Then, the catalyst research progress in electrocatalytic synthesis of H2O2 is discussed in terms of heterogeneous catalysts (noble metal catalysts, non-metallic catalysts, non-precious metal catalysts, and single-atom catalysts) as well as homogeneous catalysts (e.g., molecular catalysts). The remaining challenges and development prospects of the current research are discussed. Keywords Two-electron oxygen reduction reaction Two-electron water oxidation reaction Hydrogen peroxide Electrocatalysis Current status of research Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a crucial industrial chemical and oxidizing agent with many uses, playing a vital role in chemical synthesis, disinfection and first aid, sewage treatment, bleaching and even aircraft propulsion [1–4]. At present, H2O2 is mainly prepared industrially using the anthraquinone method, as shown in the part on the upper left of Fig. 1, which consists of the hydrogenation and oxidation of an alkyl anthraquinone precursor dissolved in an organic solvent, and ultimately extracts the H2O2 from the solvent. The anthraquinone method involves several steps, requires a massive amount of energy inputs, and generates numerous wastes, suggesting that the anthraquinone method is not suitable for H2O2 production, both from the point of view of sustainability as well as production costs [5]. Moreover, due to the instability of H2O2, there are potential safety hazards in transportation and storage after high-volume preparation, meanwhile, on-site synthesis of H2O2 with H2 and O2 may also cause accidents as the concentration of H2 reaches the explosion limit. Hence, it is essential to find a green and safe method for the preparation of H2O2. With the research and development of fuel cell, there have been an increasing number of researchers investigating the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Researchers have discovered that the two-electron reaction of ORR, which is to be avoided as much as possible in the cathodic reaction of fuel cells, can be used to prepare H2O2, and meanwhile, because the reactants and by- products of this reaction only include O2 and H2O, the purity of H2O2 will not be affected, which is a good solution from the perspective of green and environmental sustainability. Meanwhile, in the field of electrocatalysis, the two-electron water oxidation reaction (WOR) can also be used to produce H2O2. WOR has several advantages, such as high productivity due to high current activity during the test, no need to gas the reaction system with O2 during the test, and the simultaneous precipitation of O2 during the reaction enhances the diffusion of H2O2 from the electrode surface, etc. [7]. Moreover, the electricity generated from green and clean energy sources such as wind power can be used to produce H2O2, which does not affect the environment from the energy source to the products, and also solves the problem that wind power is inconvenient to be integrated into the power grid due to its unsteadiness. In the following section, the reaction pathway of ORR, WOR and the current research progress will be elaborated, and the shortcomings will be discussed. Finally, the prospects and suggestions for further development of the two-electron ORR, WOR preparing H2O2 technology will be presented. 2 Pathways and progress of the water oxidation reaction (WOR) in H2O2 production 2.1 Reaction mechanisms Water oxidation is a complex reaction with three distinct pathways, and with different amounts of electron transfer, the reaction produces three products, as shown in Fig. 2 (b) and the equations below. The most widely studied WOR is the four-electron process (4e- WOR) used in electrolysis to produce O2, which is often referred to as the oxygen precipitation reaction (OER). During the 4e- WOR process, a water molecule binds to the catalytic site and loses two H+ and e- in two steps to produce OH* and O*; another water molecule then binds to O* and loses one H+ and e- to produce OOH*, and finally loses the last H+ and e- to produce oxygen and separate from the catalytic site. Water oxidation can also produce H2O2 via the 2e- pathway and OH radicals (OH*) via the 1e- pathway. During the 2e- WOR process, a water molecule binds to the catalytic site and loses two H+ and e- in a stepwise manner, producing OH* and O*. Eventually O* binds to a water molecule and loses one H+ and e-, generating H2O2 and separating from the catalytic site. During the 1e- WOR process, a water molecule binds to the catalytic site and loses an H+ and e-, generating OH* and separating from the catalytic site. It is noteworthy that all three WORs begin with the same initial step, the formation of adsorbed OH (OH*) [8]. The following are the specific reaction equations for the different paths of the 1, 2 and 4-electron WOR: 1e- WOR: * + H 2 O → O H aq · + H + + e − E ° = 2.38 V vs . RHE 2e- WOR: 2 H 2 O → H 2 O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e − E ° = 1.76 V vs . RHE * + H 2 O → O H * + H + + e − O H * + H 2 O → H 2 O 2 + H + + e − 4e- WOR: 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e − E ° = 1.23 V vs . RHE * + H 2 O → O H * + H + + e − O H * → O * + H + + e − O * + H 2 O → OO H * + H + + e − OO H * → * + O 2 + H + + e − 2.2 Recent research of water oxidation reaction (WOR) In 2004, Ando and Tanaka [10] demonstrated for the first time that carbon materials can be used as electrocatalysts to produce H2O2 via 2e- WOR in NaOH solution. With the efforts of researchers in recent years, a series of catalysts (e.g., WO3, TiO2, BiVO4, F-SnO2 and Sb2O3, as shown in Fig. 2 (a)) have shown good 2e- WOR catalytic selectivity and activity [9]. Siahrostami et al. [11–15] have extensively studied 2e- WOR and plotted the volcano diagrams of two-electron WOR metal oxide catalysts (containing PtO2, RuO2, MnO2, ZnO, etc.) as shown in Fig. 2 (c). Among them, we can find ZnO (00−10) located at the top of the diagram with the most suitable binding energy for *OH adsorption while maintaining high selectivity for H2O2 precipitation. The ZnO (00−10) catalyst had an overpotential of 40 mV at 0.1 mA cm−2 and was able to achieve a peak H2O2 Faraday efficiency of 81%. In addition, the strongly oxygen-binding WOR catalysts and the weakly oxygen-binding WOR catalysts require huge overpotentials. However, they usually have relatively good selectivity. In order to have a wide potential window for H2O2 release via water oxidation, the ideal catalysts have suppressed selectivity for O2 and hydroxyl radical release (four-electron and one-electron oxidation, respectively). Wang et al. [16] achieved a significant increase in the selectivity and activity of H2O to H2O2 by coating a carbon catalyst with a hydrophobic polymer and limiting the in situ production of O2 gas. The maximum Faraday efficiency of H2O2 reached 66% at an overpotential of 640 mV and the rate of H2O2 production was 23.4 μmol min−1 cm−2 at a current density of 75.2 mA cm−2. In addition, the hydrophobic polymer-coated catalyst approach was extended to nickel metal, demonstrating that the method of in situ gas confinement can be effectively extended to other catalysts and has wide applicability. Hu et al. [17] successfully prepared highly efficient 2e- WOR electrocatalysts by carefully selecting the “B” site metals with the best O* and OH* adsorption properties. The researchers compared the catalysts prepared by combining three “B” site metals, Co, Ni, and Mn, with La, in which the LaCoO3 catalyst exhibited an excellent H2O2 yield of 2977.29 μmol min−1 g−1. In addition, the LaCoO3 catalyst also has good stability, and the catalysts still showed remarkable durability and stable electrochemical performance after 120 h of stability testing. 3 Pathways of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) 3.1 Reaction mechanisms ORR is a multi-step and multi-electron transfer reaction, which can be categorized into two-electron (2e-) and four-electron (4e-) reactions with different products of the reaction. Depending on the mode of O2 adsorption, ORR can also be categorized into associative and dissociative pathways. As shown in Fig. 3 (a-b), when O2 is adsorbed on the active site in Pauling mode, ORR proceeds in the associative pathway. In the active site, O2 combines with H+ as O2* and becomes OOH*, in 2e- reaction, OOH* combines with H+ to form H2O2; in 4e- reaction, OOH* combines with H+ to become O*, and O* continuously combines with H+ to form H2O [18–20]. As can be seen from the equation, the OOH* generated by the 2e- reaction can continue to combine with H+ under certain conditions to transform into a 4e- reaction, in which case the 4e- reaction is called the "2+2" e- reaction, and we should endeavor to avoid the occurrence of the "2+2" e- reaction in the 2e- ORR preparation of H2O2. Obviously, in order to obtain the H2O2 product, the O-O bond should be maintained during the ORR process. Therefore, both the adsorption/ desorption properties of the OOH* intermediate and the splitting of the O-O bond needs to be considered and controlled so that it cannot be further reduced to generate H2O (4e- ORR process). When oxygen is adsorbed on the active site as Yeager mode, ORR proceeds in a dissociation path. on the active site, O2 dissociates directly into two O* sites, and O* then combines with H+ to form H2O. Only the 4e- reaction undergoes the dissociation path. The following are the specific reaction equations for the different paths of the 2 and 4-electron ORR: 2e- ORR: O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2 O 2 E ° = 0.67 V vs . RHE Associative pathway: O 2 → O 2 * O 2 * + H + + e − → OOH * OOH * + H + + e − → H 2 O 2 4e- ORR: O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e − → H 2 OE°= 1.23 V vs. RHE Associative pathway: O 2 → O 2 * O 2 * + H + + e − → OOH * OOH * + H + + e − → O * + H 2 O O * + H + + e − → OH * OH * + H + + e − → H 2 O Dissociating pathways: O 2 → 2 O * 2 O * + 2 H + + 2 e − → 2 OH * 2 OH * + 2 H + + 2 e − → 2 H 2 O In different electrolyte environments, the mechanism of 2e- ORR will be different. In acidic electrolytes, O2 reacts directly with H+ to form H2O2; whereas in alkaline electrolytes, because H+ cannot be stabilized in the electrolyte, O2 instead reacts with H2O to form HO2 - as well as OH-. The following are the mechanism of 2e- ORR in different electrolytes condition: In acid electrolytes: O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2 O 2 Associative pathway： O 2 + * + H + + e − → * OOH * OOH + H + + e − → H 2 O 2 In alkaline electrolytes: O 2 + H 2 O + 2 e − → H O 2 − + O H − Associative pathway： O 2 + * + H 2 O + e − → * OOH + O H − * OOH + e − → * + H O 2 − The pH of the electrolyte significantly affected the performance and stability of the catalyst. It was found that for metal-based catalysts, the H2O2 selectivity of the catalysts was higher in acidic environments than in alkaline environments, and the glassy carbons showed higher 2e- ORR selectivity in alkaline environments than in acidic environments. In acidic media, the kinetic barrier for breaking O-O bonds on metal-based catalysts is higher, and O2 is more firmly bound to the active site on the catalyst, resulting in more selective production of H2O2.Therefore, the use of metal-based catalysts in acidic environments is a better strategy for the production of H2O2 [23]. However, in acidic environments, leaching of metal ions may occur, resulting in reduced catalyst stability. The 2e- ORR of carbon-based catalysts under different pH conditions has been extensively studied. There are many excellent carbon-based catalysts that exhibit high 2e- ORR selectivity and high onset potentials in alkaline electrolytes. For instance, highly defective carbon with ordered mesoporous structure exhibits excellent electrochemical performance with more than 90% H2O2 selectivity at 0.6 V in KOH solution [24]. Besides, oxidized carbon nanotubes, reduced graphene oxide and pyrolytic edge-rich nanostructures showed promising high performance as H2O2 electrocatalysts with high selectivity and onset potentials in alkaline electrolytes. Conclusively, the use of carbon-based catalysts for the preparation of H2O2 in an alkaline environment is a better strategy. For single-atom catalysts, there have been extensive studies in acidic as well as alkaline environments, but fewer studies in neutral solutions. In acidic environments, the overpotential is usually high, except for Co-N-C catalysts. As an example, the onset potential for oxygen reduction of Co-N-C varies in different pH environments, with the highest onset potential in alkaline environments, followed by acidic environments, and finally neutral environments. Between 0.8 and 0.4 V, the order of disc and ring currents was neutral < acidic < alkaline, while at < 0.4 V, the current densities in neutral and acidic environments were higher than those in acidic environments, but the ring currents showed an opposite trend [25]. As shown in Fig. 3 (c-d), the rate-determining step of the reaction is the step from *OOH to the next stage, both in the two and four-electron processes. The two-electron partial reduction pathway leads to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as a product and involves only OOH* as a reaction intermediate, whereas the four-electron reduction pathway reduces oxygen completely to water, involving four reduction steps. Typically, both the associative and dissociative pathways are considered, depending on whether or not the O2 molecule is dissociated prior to reduction. The associative pathway involves three different intermediates, OOH*, O*, and OH*, while the dissociative pathway involves only O* and OH*. The Gibbs free energy of each step of the reaction also changes when different voltages are applied. As shown in Fig. 3 (c), when the equilibrium potential of 1.23 V is applied, the Gibbs free energy of each reaction step changes, in which the hydrogenation of O2 to OOH* and the hydrogenation of OH* to H2O are in an upward slope, implying that these two steps determine the rate of the reaction, and it is obvious that the energy barrier difference of the last step of the hydrogenation of OH* to H2O is larger than the first step of the reaction, therefore, the last step is the 4e- rate determining step for ORR. As shown in Fig. 3 (d), when an equilibrium potential of 0.70 V is applied, the first step of O2 hydrogenation to OOH* tends to be uphill, implying that this step is the rate-determining step for 2e- ORR [22]. The smaller the energy barrier difference between the Gibbs free energy of the reaction and the Gibbs free energy at the equilibrium potential when the test voltage is applied to the catalyst, the more beneficial it is to promote the reaction. Since the efficiency of H2O2 preparation by 2e- ORR is mainly limited by the adsorption rate of OOH*, the catalytic performance of the catalysts for 2e- ORR and the efficiency of H2O2 preparation can be enhanced if the reaction energy barrier of binding OOH* to the catalysts' active sites can be reduced as much as possible by modulating the catalysts. 4 Electrochemical test and physiochemical characterization Rotating Ring-Disk Electrode (RRDE) is a widely used equipment for evaluating the electrochemical performance of 2e- ORR, which mainly consists of a disk electrode with a glassy carbon electrode and a ring electrode with a platinum ring electrode. In Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV) test, O2 will be converted to H2O and H2O2 by the reduction reaction on the disk electrode under the action of reduction potential, and the H2O2 generated on the disk electrode will be shifted to the ring electrode under the action of electrode rotation. The oxidation potential applied on the ring electrode will oxidize H2O2 to H2O. The monitoring of the electron transfer number and H2O2 yield is accomplished by observing the changes in the disk current and ring current. ( Fig. 4 (a)) Based on the data obtained from RRDE LSV testing, the following parameters are mainly used to evaluate the electrochemical performance of 2e- ORR: (1) The reaction potential is the most directly reflecting parameter of 2e- ORR activity, and it can be calculated from the Nernst equation to the thermodynamic equilibrium potential Eθ, which is0.70 V vs. RHE in the acidic environment and 0.86 V vs. RHE in the alkaline environment. The value of the difference between the starting potential and Eθ is the overpotential η, the smaller η is, the closer to the thermodynamic equilibrium potential Eθ is, which indicates that the higher the activity of the catalyst in 2e- ORR is. It is generally believed that the η of the catalyst with high activity should be less than 0.2 V vs. RHE. (2) The selectivity of H2O2 and the electron transfer number of the reaction are also important parameters to evaluate the catalytic performance of 2e- ORR. During the LSV test, a reductive disk current ID is generated at the disk electrode and an oxidizing ring current IR is generated at the ring electrode. Based on ID and IR, the number of electrons transferred, the Faraday Efficiency (FE), and the H2O2 selectivity of the catalyst for the ORR process at the RRDE can be calculated [30]: n = 4 × I D I R ÷ N + I D FE % = 100 × ( I R ÷ N ) I D H 2 O 2 ( % ) = 100 × 2 × ( I R ÷ N ) I R ÷ N + I D = 2 FE 1 + FE where N is the acquisition efficiency of the RRDE. (3) For practical applications, the stability of catalysts for H2O2 preparation is also an important evaluation parameter. Under the conditions of laboratory testing, a well-performing catalyst should be able to maintain stable for more than tens of hours. For long-term testing, the catalyst can be coated on carbon paper and mounted in an H-type electrolytic cell for testing to protect the RRDE device (Fig. 4 (b)). The concentration of H2O2 prepared by 2e- ORR can be determined by ceric sulfate titration coupled with UV–visible spectroscopy. As shown in the following equations, the concentration of H2O2 prepared by the reaction is twice the concentration of Ce4+ consumed [31]. 2Ce4++H2O2→2Ce3++2H++O2 M H 2 O 2 = 2 × M Ce 4 + In addition, we can also use the colorimetric strip method and the titration method to determine the yield of H2O2. Colorimetry strip method is a method of determining the content of a component to be measured by comparing or measuring the depth of color of a solution of a colored substance. This method is able to quickly determine the approximate content of a substance during an experiment. However, the exact content of the substance cannot be accurately obtained from comparing the depth of the colors alone. The titration method is based on a change in the color of the indicator to indicate the end point of the titration, followed by a visual measurement of the volume of standard solution consumed and calculation of the analytical result. Hence the titration method is capable of obtaining relatively accurate substance content, but it requires numerous procedures during the titration process, which is not conducive to obtaining results rapidly. UV–visible spectroscopy enables precise substance content to be obtained and requires fewer procedures. However, UV–visible spectroscopy requires relatively expensive equipment and is not as cost-effective as the other two methods. Combined with the time cost and the requirement for data accuracy, UV–visible spectroscopy is widely used in most studies. In practical applications, H-type electrolytic cells or gas diffusion electrodes are commonly used for the preparation of massive H2O2. However, as the H-type electrolytic cell does not facilitate removing the generated H2O2 timely, and will inhibit the 2e- ORR when the concentration of H2O2 increases, thus the H-type electrolytic cell is mainly used to test the performance of 2e- ORR catalysts under laboratory conditions. In practical industrial production situations, the gas diffusion electrode flow cell is the main device to be used. During the reaction process, O2 continuously diffuses to the surface of the catalyst through the gas diffusion layer, which maintains the O2 on the surface of the catalyst in a saturated state and provides excellent conditions for the preparation of H2O2. Meanwhile, the flow cell can keep flowing of the liquid in the system to avoid the accumulation of H2O2 near the electrodes and be further reduced to H2O, so the timely shifting of H2O2 on the electrode surface is extremely important to enhance the yield [32]. By controlling the flow rate of the liquid, the concentration of H2O2 produced by the reaction system can be modulated. In electrochemical testing, the electrolyte also has a crucial impact on the performance. Wang et al. [33] found that the addition of Na2SO4 to H2SO4 was effective in enhancing the performance of the catalyst and helped the catalyst to maintain a high FE plateau. As the concentration of added Na2SO4 increased, the current density as well as the FE of H2O2 gradually increased. They also found that the addition of other alkali metal ions could also increase the H2O2 yield. This may be due to the fact that the addition of alkali metal ions such as Na+ avoids the aggregation of H+ ions and reduces the occurrence of the reaction in which OOH* combines with H+ to form H2O, as shown in Fig. 5. During the reaction, the dissolution of metal ions may also initiate a Fenton or Fenton-like reaction leading to the decomposition of H2O2, thus affecting the stability of the catalyst production. The reactive oxygen species (e.g., ·OH and ·OOH) produced by the decomposition of H2O2 can, conversely, destroy the catalyst, leading to degradation of catalytic performance as well as a loss of stability. Therefore, another approach is to add H2O2 stabilizing additives such as anions of p-block elements such as Si, Al, Ge and Sn [34,35]. However, it is also important to ensure that the addition of such redox inert anions do not alter the pH of the solution through the use of buffered electrolytes. In addition, reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced with the reaction may lead to H2O2 decomposition. Therefore, the introduction of a radical scavenger that scavenges both oxidizing radicals (e.g., hydroxyl radicals) and reducing radicals (e.g., superoxide) could improve the total H2O2 yield. The current study considers S and Se as potential scavengers [36–38]. 5 Progress in H2O2 production by two-electron oxygen reduction Catalysts can be classified into many types in terms of state, phase of the reaction system, and type of reaction, etc. In this review, catalysts are mainly categorized in terms of the phase of the reaction system, which can be classified into heterogeneous catalysts and homogeneous catalysts. Heterogeneous catalysts can be subdivided into metallic, non-metallic catalysts, and single atom catalysts. Here, the metallic catalysts can further be subdivided into precious and non-precious metal catalysts. Homogeneous catalysts can be subdivided into acid, base, soluble transition metal compounds and peroxide catalysts. Homogeneous catalysts act independently with molecules or ions, with uniform active centers, high activity and high selectivity. 5.1 Precious metal catalysts Precious metal catalysts provide better catalytic performance and selectivity in 2e- ORR and they are the most widely used catalysts commercially. For example, Au nanoparticles bind relatively weakly to O2 and exhibit low reaction rates and high overpotentials during electrocatalytic H2O2 process, whereas some metal-based catalysts such as Pt and Pd bind strongly to O2 but are liable to undergo the 4e- pathway. According to Sabatier principle, the catalytic activity is highest when the interaction between the reactants and the catalyst surface is at an optimum, i.e., not too weak and not too strong. Current strategies to regulate the bonding strength of noble metals with O2 is mainly through the synthesis of alloy catalysts [39–42] and the introduction of carbon carriers [43-45]，as shown in Fig. 6. Although the noble metal catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity, but from the point of view of commercial cost, the high price of noble metal will undoubtedly be a burden to the commercial preparation of H2O2, so the mainstream research trend is in the preparation of non-metal or non-precious -metallic catalysts, or to reduce of the loading amount of noble metal in order to achieve the purpose of cost reduction. 5.2 Non-metallic catalysts As mentioned above, noble metals have good catalytic activity, but the lack of materials and high-cost limit large-scale applications. Carbon-based materials have received widespread attention because of their low price, easy availability, and controllable structure. However, pure carbon-based materials have low catalytic activity and selectivity when used directly as catalysts [46]. For this reason, some researchers have developed to optimize the electrocatalytic H2O2 performance of pure carbon- based materials via heteroatoms (N, B, S, P, O, etc.) doping [47], to construct some structural defects [48], or induce interface engineering [49], see Fig. 7. Additionally, the introduction of heteroatom may also change the electronic structure of carbon materials and further improve the catalytic activity of the materials. The enhancement of electrocatalytic activity is derived from electroneutrality disruption and electron transfer caused by differences in the size and electronegativity of the incorporated heteroatoms. Due to the incorporation of heteroatoms, the electronic configuration of the neighboring carbons can be changed and the charge/spin distribution on the original sp2 hybrid carbon structure can be effectively altered to optimize the chemisorption of the intermediates and thus enhance the intrinsic activity. [50] For example, Su et al. [51] found that N doping improves the catalytic activity of graphene; more interestingly, different types of N behave differently, with graphite N having the best 2e- ORR activity, followed by pyridine N, and finally by pyrrole N. N-doped carbon-based materials can achieve 75–85% selectivity under laboratory test conditions [51,52]. Meanwhile, Hu et al. [53] synthesized g-C3N4 catalysts with different N species by using different precursors, and the analysis showed that Urea-C3N4 has the best 2e- ORR activity and ∼90% H2O2 selectivity in alkaline environments. Based on the XPS results, they found that graphitic nitrogen had a significant effect on the 2e- ORR selectivity. On this basis, they prepared carbon quantum dots (CQDs)-modified graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4/CQDs-X) by controlled ultrasonic stripping, which exhibited 95% selectivity at 0.35 V vs. RHE, and obtained a H2O2 yield of 1466.6 mmol g−1 in 12 h. The addition of CQDs by sonication not only enhanced the high specific surface area and porous structure of the g-C3N4 catalyst, but also increased the conductivity and electron transfer ability, which led to the acceleration of the reaction rate [54]. In addition, Wang et al. [55] found in their study of carbon materials doped with different heteroatoms, that the most favorable adsorption sites for *OOH on B-C and P-C materials are B and P, respectively, rather than C, which is linked to the heteroatom. To dope the carbon-based material with O, the catalyst can be prepared by oxidizing the carbon-based material with concentrated HNO3 or by using graphene oxide as a feedstock. Lu et al. [31] prepared O-C catalysts with selectivity up to 90% by oxidizing carbon nanotubes through concentrated HNO3. Oxygen-doped carbon-based materials are also useful in the preparation of other of catalysts. For example, Guo et al. [57] successfully introduceda ultrahigh amount of oxygen (30.4 at%) into carbon quantum dots (CQD), and the obtained CQD catalyst had a high yield of 10.06 mg cm−2 h−1 with a Faraday efficiency of 97.7% and a good stability over 10 h. Wang et al. [29] achieved >90% H2O2 yield of 3.4 mmol cm−2 h−1 by nitric acid oxidation of functionalized carbon black catalysts for 2e- ORR. They found that the surface oxidation of the carbon material was closely related to the selectivity and activity of H2O2, which may be due to the fact that the surface oxidation increased the concentration of active sites on the material. Although these O-C catalysts have a small negligible starting overpotential for H2O2, they typically require an overpotential of several hundred milliamps per square centimeter to produce H2O2 currents comparable to those of industrial grade. The need for high overpotentials to obtain industrial grade currents may be due to the high charge transfer resistivity caused by oxidation of the catalyst surface [58–60]. Sun et al. [61] prepared honeycomb carbon nanofibers (HCNFs) catalysts by spinning PVA powder and PTFE aqueous emulsion, and the oxygen-functional group-rich hydrophilic porous carbon skeleton facilitated electron transfer and contact between electrolyte and catalyst, achieving high H2O2 selectivity of 97.3% and high quality activity of 220 A g−1. To address the problem of high charge transfer resistance for O-C surface oxidation, highly active and selective B-doped carbon was used for 2e- ORR. Furthermore, the B doping is also a good strategy to improve the intrinsic activity of pristine carbon materials. Wang et al. [62] reported the B doped carbon black showing high selectivity of about 90%. Moreover, this catalyst was able to maintain the catalytic performance at a current density of 200 mA cm−2 for at least 30 h. In this work, they also investigated the effect of B doping amount towards H2O2 activity and found that when increasing the doping amount of B, the overpotential could be enhanced by 20 mV at the same current density compared to the catalysts which did not increasing the doping amount of B. And the B-C catalyst was able to enhance the overpotential by 210 mV at a current density of 300 mA cm−2 compared to the O-doped C catalyst previously studied by Wang et al. [29] CO2-derived edge B-doped porous carbon materials were prepared for the efficient production of H2O2 by Lee et al. [63] In their study, it was found that the oxidized B-doped configurations (BCO2 and BC2O) at the edge positions were the main reason for the catalyst's ability to enhance the 2e- ORR activity and stability. 5.3 Non-precious metal catalysts As described above, heteroatom-doped carbon-based material can dramatically improve its catalytic activity and selectivity of H2O2, but it is found that theses non-metal catalysts are not enough to bring the catalysts to the level of commercialization in practical applications. Therefore, researcher have begun to consider loading transition metals (TMs) onto carbon-based materials to optimum catalysts' performance improved by constructing structural defects or surface modification. In the beginning, due to the simplicity and reproducibility of the experiments, researchers loaded metal particles or clusters onto carbon-based materials to prepare catalysts. Huang et al. [64] prepared catalysts by distributing NiO nanoparticles into NiFe-MOF nanosheets, and the H2O2 selectivity of the resulting catalysts could even reach 99%. Niu et al. [65] introduced FeOX nanoparticles into N-doped layered porous carbon materials, and the resulting catalysts also achieved 95% H2O2 selectivity. Rawah et al. [66] introduced cobalt nanoparticles into nitrogen-doped carbon materials, and the resulting catalyst continuously catalyzed the reaction for 2 h at 0.3 V vs. RHE, with a H2O2 production rate of 100 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and a high H2O2 Faraday efficiency of close to 85%. To find out the best non-precious metal, researchers studied a variety of metals, as shown in Fig. 8, such as Ni [67–70], Fe [71], Cu [72], Zn [73,74], Bi [75], Mg [76], Co [22,77–80], etc. Among these catalytic materials, the Co-based materials exhibited the optimal H2O2 catalytic activity. Despite the good catalytic activity of NiO catalysts, poor stability is still a major problem. In the study by Wu et al. [68], the NiO catalysts were tested for stability with a slight decrease in both disk and ring currents, and the tested samples were subjected to SEM analysis, which revealed that the microstructure was damaged to a certain extent, which was supposed to be the reason for the performance degradation. The isolated metal atoms in most cases interact directly with the oxygenated intermediates during the ORR process. Hence, the catalytic performance of M-N-C catalysts depends largely on the center metal M. Through theoretical calculations as well as experimental proofs, Gao et al. [81] systematically investigated the structures of Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu atoms anchoring N-doped graphene and their relationship with the 2e- ORR performance. As shown in Fig. 9, DFT calculations showed that the binding energies of OOH*, O*, and OH* are usually inversely proportional to the number of valence electrons in the M atoms. The lower energy barrier possessed by Co atoms results in the higher activity and catalytic performance of Co-N-C catalysts. Besides, Jung et al. [82] loaded Co onto nitrogen-doped graphene, and the resulting Co-N4 sites exhibited a kinetic current density of 2.8 mA cm−2 and a mass activity of 155 A g−1 at 0.65 V vs. RHE, and had good stability with negligible loss of activity over 110 h. From theoretical calculations, Co-based catalysts have a low energy barrier, and from practical tests, Co-based catalysts also have good performance and stability, so many researchers are currently investigating Co-based catalysts. In current research, many Co-containing catalysts are able to achieve greater than 90% H2O2 selectivity, so Co and its modified catalysts have aroused the wide interest of researchers. For example, Yao et al. [84] designed a series catalysts with three sizes of Co species (single atom, cluster and nanoparticle), the Co-N bonds in Co clusters accelerated the speed of electron transfer. Meanwhile, Co clusters promotes the shift of the O2 adsorption configuration to the Yeager mode, which enhances the adsorption and activation of O2 and consequently boosts the catalytic performance. In addition to binding to carbon materials, α-MoO3-x transition metal oxide catalysts with controllable oxygen vacancies were prepared by Hu et al. [85]. By modulating the reaction temperature and oxygen vacancies of the samples, the α-MoO3-x-400 catalyst was able to achieve more than 93% selectivity and 87% Faraday efficiency at 0.4 V vs. RHE. Moreover, the cubic tungsten trioxide (c-WO3) catalyst developed by Hu et al. [86] through a phase modulation strategy exhibited a high selectivity of ∼90% and an H2O2 yield of 179 mmol gcat−1 h−1 at 0.1 V vs. RHE, and the continuous reaction for 24 h did not decrease the H2O2 generation rate. Hu et al. [87] also prepared NiFe layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) catalysts capable of achieving a Faraday efficiency of 88.75% for the preparation of H2O2 under alkaline conditions. In addition, the catalyst possessed OER catalytic properties with an overpotential of 210 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and high stability in 1 M KOH. On this basis, a new reactor was designed to electrolyze oxygen and generate hydrogen peroxide. The H2O2 yield reached 47.62 mmol gcat−1 h−1 at an ultra-low cell voltage of 1 V. Using a 1.5 V dry cell as a power source, the H2O2 yield reached 83.90 mmol gcat−1 h−1. Sun et al. [88] found that Ti2O3 catalysts will form oxygen-deficient TiO2 catalysts in situ during the ORR process, and the reaction pathway shifted from the 4e- ORR pathway to the 2e- ORR pathway, and more than 90% of the FE was obtained in the synthesis of H2O2. 5.4 Single-atom catalysts With the development of the research, researchers found that ordinary metal catalysts would have metal agglomeration during the catalytic process leading to the reduction of catalytic sites and weakening the catalytic performance, as well as for the purpose of reducing the amount of metal used, researchers investigated single-atom catalysts (SACs). With up to 100% atom utilization, SACs are considered to have great potential to reduce the use of precious metal catalysts. Rather than simply complementing the original ORR electrocatalysts (i.e., precious metal catalysts, non-precious metal catalysts, and carbon-based materials), SACs can be viewed as an important conceptual advancement that can radically improve the performance of all types of catalysts [89]. 2e- ORR selectivity is highly dependent on the nature of the catalyst surface. Changing the arrangement of surface atoms from contiguous to isolated sites is crucial for controlling the reaction selectivity. When the monatomic active sites are wrapped with inert elements, the selectivity of the catalyst can be substantially improved. For example, Rossmeisl et al. [90] utilized the concept of isolated active sites to regulate the activity and selectivity of oxygen reduction. Their theoretical modeling successfully predicted Pt-Hg as an active, selective, and stable catalyst for hydrogen peroxide synthesis. The Pt-Hg catalysts produced hydrogen peroxide with efficiencies as high as 96% in the region between 0.2 and 0.4 V. Within these potential limits, the hydrogen peroxide current density is 3 mA cm−2, which is the theoretical mass transfer limit for the two-electron reduction of oxygen. Only at potentials below 0.2 V do selectivity and hydrogen peroxide current begin to decrease, which means that water formation is favored. In the current study, SACs with inherently isolated active sites have shown great advantages in meeting electrochemical H2O2 production. As shown in Fig. 3 (a-b), atomically dispersed catalysts are more inclined to adsorb oxygen molecules via the Pauling mode (end-on adsorptions), giving them dominant 2e- ORR selectivity. The unsaturated coordination environments of SACs can efficiently modulate the electronic structure, thus improving the ORR performance. Maximum atomic utilization efficiency and homogeneous reaction sites have led to the widespread use of SACs. In order to immobilize the metal atom sites, carbon-based materials are seen as ideal substrates, which are usually bonded in the form of anchoring or coordinating. Since SACs have the characteristic of low metal loading but high catalytic activity, SACs with noble metals show comparable or superior catalytic performance to other catalysts (e.g., nanoparticle or metal cluster catalysts) even with much lower noble metal loading. The ability to approach the activity of PGM catalysts while reducing the precious metal loading can greatly reduce the cost when used commercially, thus making SACs one of the catalysts currently under mainstream research in any electrocatalytic research area. Yang et al. [91] prepared a TiN nanoparticle-loaded single-atom Pt catalyst with about 0.35 wt% of Pt. It was found that the single-atom Pt catalyst preferred 2e- ORR for the preparation of H2O2 as compared to commercial Pt/C. Jiang et al. [92] loaded Fe, Pd, Co, and Mn single atoms onto carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as shown in Fig. 10, and found that the Fe-CNT catalysts were highly selective for H2O2 over 95% at both alkaline and neutral pH. The aggregation of single atoms into clusters is also a major problem affecting the performance of single-atom catalysts. Shen et al. prepared single-atom catalysts capable of achieving 24.8 at% Pt atom content and H2O2 selectivity of about 90% by loading Pt on sulfide carriers and utilizing the strong interaction force between Pt-S to avoid the interconnection of clusters between Pt single atoms, and this work provides a great contribution in solving the problem of cluster formation by single atoms [93]. Although metal nanoparticles or clusters can provide better catalytic activity, the particles or clusters may agglomerate over a long period of time, leading to a decrease in active sites and affecting the catalytic activity. For this reason, researchers have developed single-atom catalysts. In single-atom catalysts, the main active sites are M-N-C or MNX (M is a metal such as Fe, Cu, Co, etc.). Take Co as an example, the Co-N-C structure can play a good 2e- ORR catalytic performance and selectivity in a large number of studies. The Co-N-C catalysts prepared by Chen et al. [94] were able to achieve 94% selectivity under acidic condition, and were also able to carry out the H2O2 preparation stably for 90 h in the flow cell. In addition to Co-N-C, other elements such as O replaced some or all of the N in M-N-C, and the electron arrangement on M was changed by the influence of O, resulting that some of the MN4 sites, which were originally 4e- ORR catalytic active converts into MOX or MOXNY sites with higher 2e- ORR catalytic activity and higher H2O2 selectivity. 5.5 Homogeneous catalysts Homogeneous catalysts are also key catalysts for electrocatalytic production of H2O2. Herein, homogeneous catalysts are also summarized in this review. Compared with heterogeneous catalysts, homogeneous catalysts have some advantages: single reaction performance with specific selectivity; mild reaction conditions, which is conductive to energy saving; and because of its clear mechanism, it is easy to carefully design and deploy research and grasp. The main disadvantages of homogeneous catalysts are poor stability and difficulty in separating from the product. One of the main focuses of the research is the solidification of homogeneous catalysts, which is the anchoring of active component metal atoms to ionomers, such as organic polymers like polyvinyl chloride (PVC) and ion-exchange resins, or inorganic polymers like carbon-based materials, SiO2, and molecular sieves. In the study of 2e- ORR, the researchers mainly used molecular catalysts such as metal phthalocyanines (Pc) and porphyrins (Por) to binding with the carriers to modulate the catalytic performance. Organic molecules such as Pc and Por have known structures, shown in Fig. 11 (a-d), in which the metal M atom of Pc has four N atoms stably attached around it, and the C atoms around the M atom are then attached to another four N atoms to form the structure of M-N4+4; while the metal M atom of Por has four N atoms attached around it to form the structure of M-N4. In a certain extent, the previously mentioned M-N-C structure is also inspired by the structure of molecular catalysts, because the catalytic site in many M-N-C structured catalysts is M-N4, which is similar to the form of M-N bonding in molecular catalysts. However, since the structure of organic molecules becomes less stable in practice due to the presence of acids and alkalis, as well as the effect of potentials, it is impractical to use only Pc or Por for a long time preparation, so Smith et al. [97] loaded Pc onto carbon nanotubes oxidized by concentrated HNO3, protected by the carbon-based material, the Pc was able to stably provide the active site for the preparation of H2O2, meanwhile, the oxidized O on the carbon nanotubes also participated in the reaction, resulting in 90% H2O2 selectivity of the CoPc-CNT(O) catalyst. At the same time, Fan et al. [96] also loaded CoPc onto CNTs, and the H2O2 selectivity could reach 95%. In addition, he made predictions on the activity and selectivity of different MPc (M=Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) on each reaction pathway of ORR by theoretical calculations as shown in Fig. 11 (e). Liu et al. [98] also loaded CoPor onto carbon nanotubes and obtained catalysts with H2O2 selectivity of 90%. Therefore, molecular catalysts have great potential for application, and the catalytic activity as well as stability can be further enhanced by doping of heteroatoms and modulation of surface defects. On the basis of loaded carbon nanotubes, Yu et al. [99] improved the performance of the catalysts by using hydrophobic ionic away from the surface of the catalysts, preventing them from decomposing rapidly into H2O, and thus improving the H2O2selectivity. Compared with the catalyst without IL coating, the catalyst with an optimal thickness of 8 nm IL coating can provide nearly four times the current density and 12.5% H2O2 selectivity, with FE up to 92%. In a two-electrode electrolyzer test, a production efficiency of 3.71 molH2O2 gcat −1 h−1 and good stability were demonstrated. 6 Conclusions and challenges So far, the electrocatalytic synthesis of hydrogen peroxide has focused on the partial reduction of oxygen molecules at the cathode using a series of catalysts such as noble metals and their alloys, heteroatom-doped nonmetallic catalysts, nonprecious transition metal M-N-C complexes, and homogeneous catalysts. In Table 1, we summarize the application environments and H2O2 selectivity of some noble, non-precious, non-metallic, and homogeneous catalysts. However, since ORR requires O2 to participate in the reaction, the amount of H2O2 produced will still be limited by the diffusion of O2 into the catalyst surface in the electrolyte, regardless of the difference between the applied potential and the reversible potential of 2e- ORR. Since RRDE can only be used as a test of catalyst performance in a laboratory environment and does not allow for large-scale preparation of H2O2, in practical large-scale operations, such as applying gas diffusion electrodes or PEMFC assemblies, the selectivity seems to be significantly lower than that measured with RRDE assemblies. 2e- WOR, although it is unaffected by the diffusion of O2 through the electrolyte, and is able to produce a relatively large amount of H2O2, it still needs further improvement in selectivity. Unfortunately, the number of reported catalysts for 2e- WOR is much lower than the total number of reported catalysts for two-electron ORR. This clearly implies that increased attention needs to be paid to the anodic 2e- WOR synthesis of H2O2. To enhance the selectivity and yield of H2O2 prepared by 2e- ORR and WOR, the following improvements can be considered: 1) Changing the arrangement of surface atoms from continuous sites to isolated sites is crucial for controlling the reaction selectivity. The isolated site property that SACs possess can effectively enhance the H2O2 selectivity, but there are fewer catalytic sites in the current SACs (generally less than 1 wt%), so boosting the number of catalytic sites in the SACs is an effective way to enhance the catalytic performance and selectivity. For example, Yin et al. [120] synthesized high metal loaded cobalt metal based SACs with more than 4 wt% by pyrolysis, Shen et al. [93] increased the Pt atomic content to 24.8 at% by constructing a Pt-S structure, all these works show us that there is still a development potential for the high loaded SACs. 2) Besides the catalyst itself, the electrolyte is also a point of interest. For example, Wang et al. added alkali metal ions such as Na+ into the H2SO4 electrolyte, and the presence of Na+ avoids the aggregation of H+ and promotes the generation of H2O2, which improves the catalytic activity and selectivity. Another scheme is to add H2O2 stabilizing additives such as Si, Al, Ge and other elements to the electrolyte to avoid the decrease of H2O2 yield caused by the rapid decomposition of H2O2 after its generation. All the above schemes can provide inspiration for us in applying electrolyte engineering to optimize the catalytic activity and yield. 3) After the catalyst is prepared, the performance of the catalyst can be tested by selecting different pH test environments according to the type of catalyst, for example, the noble metal catalyst should be tested in an acidic environment, the carbon-based catalyst in an alkaline environment, and the monoatomic catalyst in an acidic or alkaline environment. The use of suitable test environments can enable the catalyst to achieve better catalytic performance and thus better preparation of H2O2. In order to solve the problem of metal catalyst leaching in acidic environments, it can be tried to wrap a porous protective layer outside the metal to ensure that O2 is in contact with the active site to prepare H2O2 while minimizing the leaching of the metal and maintaining the stability of the catalyst. 4) Precious metal catalysts have high catalytic activity, but their high price hinders their large-scale application. Precious metal or non-precious metal monoatomic catalysts usually have good catalytic selectivity but poor stability. Carbon-based materials have the advantages of high electrical conductivity and high mass-transfer porosity, but poor catalytic performance. Consequently, catalysts with high catalytic activity and high stability can be prepared by loading noble and non-precious metals onto carbon-based materials, combining the high catalytic activity of metals and the stability of carbon-based materials. When we applied the catalyst to devices such as gas diffusion electrodes or PEMFCs, the selectivity obtained seems to be significantly lower than that measured by the RRDE component, most likely owing to the fact that the sufficiently homogeneous diffusion of O2 improves the selectivity in the RRDE test, whereas the diffusion of O2 in the device is limited. Therefore, one possible improvement is to use, for example, electrodes with special coatings added to improve the diffusion of O2 in the device, while allowing H2O2 to detach from the catalyst surface in time to release the active sites to continue binding with O2, with higher catalytic site utilization also leading to higher catalytic performance. Another option is to combine 2e- ORR and 2e- WOR to form a device, where 2e- ORR occurring at the cathode and 2e- WOR occurring at the anode are able to produce H2O2 simultaneously, but the different voltages and reaction conditions required for the two reactions may be challenging for the device, which still needs to be further explored. coredata.dc:description: The preparation of Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) by electrochemical two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e- ORR) and water oxidation reaction (2e- WOR) is a highly desirable method that can be green, clean and safe. However, the sluggish reaction kinetics and poor 2e- ORR and WOR selectivity severely limits scale-up applications. To resolve these challenges, research on cost-effective catalysts have been intensively explored, which have made great progress. Herein, we first introduced the fundamental chemistry and catalytic mechanism of ORR and WOR, including the possible reaction pathways, the binding modes of oxygen and water on the catalytic sites, and the energy-barrier diagrams of each stage of the reaction obtained by theoretical calculations. Then, the current progress of catalyst research for electrocatalytic synthesis of H2O2 is discussed. Among them, single-atom catalysts as well as molecular catalysts are the hot spots of current research. Single-atom catalysts can reduce the amount of precious or non-precious metals used, and maintain catalytic activity while reducing costs; meanwhile, molecular catalysts have the advantages of single reaction performance, high selectivity, and clear mechanism, which are easy to design and grasp. Finally, on the basis of previous studies, the remaining challenges and development prospects of the current research on electrocatalytic production of H2O2 are discussed, and suggestions are provided for the development of this field in the future.
